revision.text:
{{Update|date=January 2018}}{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}{{Use British English|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = YouView TV Ltd/Project Canvas | logo = [[File:YouView logo.png|200px]] | logo_caption = YouView original logo (now superseded) | type = [[Limited company]] | industry = [[Television]] [[broadcasting]] | predecessor = Project Canvas | foundation = 16 September 2010
(launched July 2012) in [[London]], [[England]] | founder = [[BT Group]]
[[BBC]]
[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] | hq_location = 3rd Floor, 10 [[Lower Thames Street]], London, UK | area_served = [[United Kingdom]] | key_people = {{nowrap|Simon Duffy, [[Chairman]]}}
{{nowrap|Richard Halton, [[CEO]]}} | products = [[Digital terrestrial television in the United Kingdom|Digital terrestrial television]] [[set-top box]]es | services = [[IPTV]], [[Electronic program guide|electronic programme guide]], [[video on demand]], [[Digital video recorder|digital video recording]] | owner = [[BT Group]]
[[TalkTalk Group]]
[[Arqiva]]
[[BBC]]
[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]
[[Channel 4]]
[[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] | homepage = [https://www.YouView.com https://www.YouView.com] }} '''YouView''' is a hybrid [[television]] platform in the United Kingdom, developed by a partnership of three [[telecommunications]] operators and four broadcasters. It was formed from a project originally titled ''Project Canvas'', which was rebranded as YouView in September 2010. The service was due to launch by the end of that year, but was delayed until 4 July 2012. At its launch, YouView's chairman [[Alan Sugar]] stated his ambition for the service to replace [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] devices. YouView provides access to free-to-air [[digital terrestrial television]] (DTT) channels (both DVB-T and [[DVB-T2]] channels in common with the [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] television platform) and to [[TV on demand]] (catch-up TV) services via a 'hybrid' [[set-top box]] (STB) purchased by users, connected with both a [[Internet access#Broadband access|broadband internet connection]] ''and'' a normal [[television aerial]]. No contract is required, and there is no subscription charge. Catch-up and on-demand content is delivered over the internet, which may be chargeable by the [[Internet service provider]] (ISP), or subject to limits and [[fair usage clause]]s. [[BT Group|BT]] and [[TalkTalk Group|TalkTalk]] have each partnered with YouView, allowing BT subsidiaries [[BT TV]] and [[Plusnet]] TV, and [[TalkTalk TV]] customers to access the service, along with BT's and TalkTalk's own offerings. Both companies provide customers with their own branded YouView set-top box. ==YouView content== The YouView hardware is a [[digital terrestrial television]] [[DVB-T2]] HD set-top box that provides viewing and recording of all free-to-air channels available on [[digital terrestrial television in the United Kingdom]]. There is no access to some streamed channels in the 225-256 range on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]],{{cite web|url=http://www.a516digital.com/p/youview-channel-listing.html|title=YouView channel list - BT TV, TalkTalk TV, Plusnet TV|author=|date=|website=a516digital}} as YouView lacks support for the [[MHEG-5]] integration channel used by these channels to provide them over IP.{{clarify|date=October 2017}} Additional content is provided over a broadband internet connection, and can be accessed via the YouView menu and [[EPG]] via the search function. There are{{when|date=October 2017}} ten free catch up TV players available, providing access to TV programming and movies: [[BBC iPlayer]], [[ITV Hub]], [[All 4]], [[My5]], [[STV Player]], [[Milkshake!]], [[UKTV Play]], [[S4C]], POP FUN and [[Quest (TV channel)|Quest]]. The content on ITV Hub varies by region. STV Player is only available in [[STV Group (Scotland)|STV Group]] regions. {{Cite news|url=https://www.youview.com/entertainment/|title=Entertainment - YouView|work=YouView|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-GB}} There are an additional three pay TV [[Video on demand|on-demand]] players: [[Netflix]], [[Now TV (Sky plc)|Now TV]], and Sky Store from [[Sky (United Kingdom)|Sky]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youview.com/whats-on/#Catchup|title=Home - YouView|author=|date=|website=YouView}} ===YouView from BT=== {{Main|BT TV}} [[BT Infinity]] subscribers can access additional live [[IPTV]] channels via the EPG. Customers who subscribe to BT TV will receive either a YouView+ (YouView plus) box (with recording capabilities), or a standard YouView box (no recording capabilities), or a YouView [[Ultra-high-definition television|Ultra HD]] box - depending on the subscription type taken. They can then view on-demand content through the BT TV Player.{{cite web|url=https://www.shop.bt.com/category/electronics,tv-and-home-entertainment,digiboxes-and-recorders/11225|title=Digiboxes, BT YouView & Freeview Recorders - BT Shop|author=|date=|website=www.shop.bt.com}} Subscribers to BT Infinity who are not BT TV subscribers, and have bought their YouView boxes from retail vendors, will have their product's YouView branding replaced by BT TV branding. They will also get the BT TV player on the starting page, which they cannot use because they are not BT TV subscribers. This has not been popular with these users, and there appears to be no way of restoring the YouView branding or removing the BT TV Player.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} ===YouView from TalkTalk=== {{Main|TalkTalk TV}} A free YouView box is provided to TalkTalk Plus or Essentials customers taking out a fixed term contract and allow access to the content previously available from TalkTalk TV. Content that TalkTalk provides, such as film rentals and box sets, are available from the TalkTalk Player [[application software|application]] within the YouView menu bar. In the TalkTalk Player, there are 'boosts' that customers can buy for a minimum of one month, and customers can watch and record them from the main guide the same as Freeview channels. These boosts range from Sky premium channels, sports, TV box sets, films, and foreign language channels. TalkTalk use their own brand of [[Huawei]]-manufactured boxes, with the TalkTalk logo on the front, a remote control with a direct button on the TalkTalk Player, and a 320 [[Gigabyte|GB]] hard drive for Plus TV customers. Essentials customers cannot record, but can still pause live TV. Unlike BT, you do not need a fibre broadband package. ===Expand to other platforms=== On 29 July 2013 it was revealed that the YouView partners intended to launch the service on [[smartphone]]s, [[tablet computer|tablets]], and [[smart TV]]s, three days after [[BSkyB]] announced the £10 [[Now TV (Sky plc)|Now TV]] set-top box which streams on demand content.https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/10209196/YouView-to-launch-on-tablets-and-smart-TVs.html YouView to launch on tablets and smart TVs ==History== '''''Project Canvas''''' was initially announced on 11 December 2008 as a partnership between the BBC, BT and ITV plc. It followed the failure of [[Kangaroo (video on demand)|Project Kangaroo]], a proposed video-on-demand service offering content from [[BBC Worldwide]], [[ITV.com]], and Channel 4's 4oD, which was blocked on competition grounds, and ended up as the [[SeeSaw (Internet television)|SeeSaw]] internet television service. Project Canvas differed from Kangaroo, however, in that it was a proposed TV platform (a device that would deliver internet-connected TV), rather than a video-on-demand service (that would act as a single content portal, much like the music video equivalent [[VEVO]]). On 30 July 2009, Project Canvas announced that Five had signed up to the project.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=First-Developer-Article|title=Five enters canvas partnership|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=30 July 2009|accessdate= }} On 9 July 2010, Five announced that it would not pursue further involvement in Project Canvas, pending a review of its digital investment strategy. Charles Constable, Director of Strategy at Five said: "We continue to support the objectives of Project Canvas, and despite withdrawing our interest in the venture we believe it will be a critical part of our strategy for reaching consumers in the future."{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-moves-forward-as-Five-departs|title=Project Canvas moves forward as Five departs|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=9 July 2010|accessdate= }} On 24 August 2010, Five re-joined Project Canvas, following their acquisition by [[Northern & Shell]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Five-comes-back-to-Project-Canvas|title=Five comes back to Project Canvas|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=24 August 2010|accessdate= }} On 16 December 2009, Project Canvas announced that Channel 4 and TalkTalk had also signed up to the project.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Channel-4-and-Talk-Talk-join-Project-Canvas--Six-partners-invite-expressions-of-interest|title=Channel 4 and Talk Talk join Project Canvas – Six partners invite 'expressions of interest'|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=16 December 2009|accessdate= }} The six partners invited any further expressions of interest from companies interested in becoming part of the joint venture. The canvas partners proposed that all prospective venture partners should be granted an equal proportion of shares in the new joint venture company. Interested parties had until 23 April 2010 to express their interest.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-partners-announce-closing-date-for-expressions-of-interest|title=Project Canvas partners announce closing date for expressions of interest|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=30 March 2010|accessdate= }} On 22 March 2010 transmission firm [[Arqiva]] joined as an equal partner in the project.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-submits-merger-analysis-to-OFT-as-Arqiva-join-as-partner|title=Project Canvas submits merger analysis to OFT, as Arqiva join as partner|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=22 March 2010|accessdate= }} On 17 May 2010 the then Project Canvas director Richard Halton said: "We have also put out an invitation for an eighth partner, and we would like a company that can add scale and expertise to the platform. It is a question of finding an organisation that shares the aims of the venture."{{cite news|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100517-703564.html|title=Interview: Project Canvas looks for eighth partner|website=WSJ.com|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=17 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520041129/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100517-703564.html|archivedate=20 May 2010}} It was later reported that, [[EE (telecommunications company)|EE]], the UK operations of [[Orange (UK)|Orange]] and [[T-Mobile (UK)|T-Mobile]], had decided against joining, after holding advanced discussions.{{Cite web|url=http://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/project-canvas-launches-web-tv-service-ftimes-7cf1289521a2.html|title=Project Canvas launches web TV service|website=Yahoo.com|publisher=Yahoo! Finance|date=16 September 2010|accessdate= }} There are three main elements to the project: setting the [[technical standard]], building the [[Computing platform|technical platform]], and creating the [[user experience]]. The BBC and other broadcasters with investments in YouView have announced intentions to sell their shares. {{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/feb/04/bbc-to-slash-youview-investment|title=BBC to slash YouView investment|last=Garside|first=Juliette|date=2014-02-04|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-08}} An on-demand service for by Sony's UK Kids channel POP was released via a software update on 10 January 2018 called POP FUN.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youview.com/2017/01/10/youview-set-first-home-sonys-kids-player/|title=YouView is set to be first home for Sony's kids player - YouView|website=www.youview.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-08}} ===Management=== On 23 July 2010 [[Kip Meek]] was announced as the non-executive chairman of Project Canvas.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Kip-Meek-to-become-chairman-of-Project-Canvas|title=Kip Meek to become chairman of Project Canvas|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=23 July 2010|accessdate= }} Meek led the Board, and oversaw the appointment of Richard Halton as CEO from programme director. Meek stepped down from his full-time role at [[Ingenious Media]] and his non-executive positions at the [[Broadband Stakeholder Group]] and [[Phorm]] to take the job. As chair, Meek was paid £97,000 during his eight-month tenure.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/jan/07/lord-sugar-paid-500000-chair-youview|author=Mark Sweney|title=Lord Sugar paid £500,000 to chair YouView|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=7 January 2013|accessdate= }} Meek left YouView on 7 March 2011, and was replaced by [[Alan Sugar]] with immediate effect,{{Cite web|url=http://www.YouView.com/2011/03/07/kip-meek-leaves-role-as-youview-non-executive-chairman/|title=Kip Meek leaves role as YouView Non-Executive Chairman|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView|date=7 March 2011|accessdate= }} who was brought on board by Channel 5's [[Richard Desmond]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.BroadcastNow.co.uk/news/multi-platform/lord-sugar-to-cure-or-kill-youview/5025249.article|title=Lord Sugar to 'cure or kill' YouView|website=BroadcastNow.co.uk|publisher=BroadcastNow|date=23 March 2011|accessdate= }} The move was partly based on his experience with set-top boxes, in particular that of Sky, and partly due to his likely influence in retaining confidence in the various partners. Sugar was paid £500,000 for chairing YouView for the year ending March 2012. Alan Sugar stepped down as Chairman in March 2013,{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/9903537/Lord-Sugar-out-at-YouView-after-bust-up-with-Richard-Desmond.html|title=Lord Sugar out at YouView after bust up with Richard Desmond|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=1 March 2013|accessdate= }} with TalkTalk group chairman [[Charles Dunstone|Sir Charles Dunstone]] taking on the chairmanship as an interim position.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/mar/05/talktalk-charles-dunstone-youview-chairman|title=TalkTalk's Sir Charles Dunstone named interim YouView chairman|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 March 2013|accessdate= }} In October 2013 [[Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment]] chairman Simon Duffy was named as non-executive chairman of YouView on a permanent basis.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/oct/16/youview-simon-duffy-chairman|title=Simon Duffy named as non-executive chairman of YouView|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 October 2013}} ==Development== On 13 November 2009, [[BBC Future Media and Technology]] director [[Erik Huggers]] previewed the work-in-progress user interface that could power the Project Canvas at [[C21 Media]]'s FutureMedia conference in London.{{Cite web|url=http://paidContent.co.uk/article/419-bbcs-huggers-gives-project-canvas-iptv-preview-says-were-not-doing-soci/|title=BBC's Huggers shows off Project Canvas possibities; says "we're not doing social networking"|website=paidContent.co.uk|publisher=paidContent:UK|date=13 November 2009|accessdate=15 October 2017}} The mock-up of how the [[2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing Olympic Games]] would look on Canvas allowed users to watch highlights instantly, send clips to friends, monitor what's being said on [[Twitter]], access archives at the touch of a button, and use commercial third party applications and services. Following the [[BBC Trust]]'s provisional approval of the BBC's participation, the partners formed a new [[joint venture]] to develop the [[Technical standard|technical specification]] for devices with standards body the [[Digital TV Group]] (DTG), create and market a new consumer [[brand]], build a common user experience, and build the technology platform. All technical specifications must be clearly published to allow manufacturers to adapt to the new Canvas standard. The BBC initially began working with three innovation partners; [[Technicolor SA]], [[Humax]], and [[Cisco Systems]]; from the consumer device manufacturing sector on the development of the Canvas core technical specifications. The relationships have [[non-disclosure agreement]]s (NDAs), non-binding collaboration agreements, and agreements ensuring any [[intellectual property]] (IP) the trio develop can be shared with the industry.{{Cite web|url=http://paidContent.co.uk/article/419-behind-the-canvas-box-makers-aboard-a-gauntlet-thrown-to-sky/|title=Behind the Canvas: box makers aboard, a gauntlet thrown to Sky|website=paidContent.co.uk|publisher=paidContent:UK|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= }} On 5 March 2010, in a '[[Question#Responses|questions and answers]]' (Q&A) session at the DTG Summit, Richard Halton, then programme director for Project Canvas, confirmed that Canvas has direct collaboration relationships with various manufacturers and industry players – including Cisco, Technicolor, Humax, [[Intel]], [[LG Corporation|LG Group]], and [[Broadcom]] – and Halton stressed that collaboration with the DTG was "absolutely critical" to the project's future success. The system offers access to the broadcasters' own [[video on demand]] (VOD), but has also promised to offer a [[Software development kit|software developers' kit]] (SDK) to encourage internet content on to the screen.{{Cite web|url=http://paidContent.co.uk/article/419-canvas-approved-benefits-outweigh-possible-slowdown-in-pay-tv-growth/|title=Canvas approved: benefits outweigh possible slowdown in pay-TV growth|website=paidContent.co.uk|publisher=paidContent:UK|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= }} Canvas also promised to offer payment mechanisms to content owners who wish to charge for their content. Speaking on 25 February 2010, [[BT TV|BT Vision]] chief executive Marc Watson announced that the project was targeting a commercial launch within the next 12 months, initially aimed at the UK's 10 million [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] households as a starting point.{{Cite news|url=https://www.TheGuardian.com/media/2010/feb/26/project-canvas-launch|title=Project Canvas set for launch within 12 months|website=TheGuardian.com|publisher=The Guardian|date=26 February 2010|location=London|first=Maggie|last=Brown|accessdate=22 May 2010}} Open technical standards required for third-party developers to create services for the Canvas platform would be published in the summer. He added that a management group, called The Venture, would run the platform in a neutral, non-discriminatory way, and that should [[Sky UK|BSkyB]] wish to take part, it would apply to this body, which is not influenced by individual corporate considerations. On 7 May 2010, Project Canvas submitted key documents to the [[Digital TV Group]] (DTG), making the next set of technical specifications available to industry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-submits-technical-documents-to-DTG|title=Project Canvas submits technical documents to DTG|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=7 May 2010|accessdate= }} The publication of these documents is in addition to Project Canvas partners' active participation in the DTG Connected TV working groups. This DTG work was to result in publication of the UK Connected TV Specification: D-Book 7, by December 2010. In addition to the previously available Consumer Device Platform Specification and Broadcast Content Delivery Specification, further documents were published in the members' area of the DTG website; including the Consumer Device Software Management Specification, IP Content Delivery Specification, and System Metadata Model. On 6 July 2010 Project Canvas published information on its content protection strategy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-sets-out-content-protection-aproach|title=Project Canvas sets out content protection approach|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=6 July 2010|accessdate= }} Providers can choose to make content available with no protection at all, or adopt transport encryption, file encryption, device authentication, or [[digital rights management]] (DRM). [[Conditional access]] (CA) upgrade will also be possible for those who require it. For providers of premium content, Canvas will support [[Marlin (DRM)|Marlin]] as the required DRM solution, at launch, which has been developed over the past five years by [[Intertrust Technologies Corporation|Intertrust]], [[Panasonic]], [[Philips]], [[Samsung]], and [[Sony]]. The selection of Marlin follows widespread industry engagement with content owners, content distributors, device manufacturers, and [[internet service provider]]s (ISPs), from which it was concluded that a common DRM solution present on all devices at launch, and widely supported by content providers would benefit all industry participants. Marlin is referenced in Release 1 of the [[Open IPTV Forum]] specifications, and therefore has the potential to be widely adopted as a part of internet-connected TV device deployments worldwide. On 11 August 2010, the Project Canvas partners formally invited expressions of interest from consumer equipment manufacturers to develop and bring Canvas devices to market in 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=Project-Canvas-partners-further-engage-with-device-manufacturers|title=Project Canvas partners further engage with device manufacturers|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=11 August 2010|accessdate= }} By the 25 August deadline, more than forty organisations had expressed their support for the Project Canvas, representing a broad range of consumer device manufacturers; including [[set-top box]]es, [[Internet television|internet-enabled TVs]], and recorders.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=INDUSTRY-GETS-BEHIND-PROJECT-CANVAS|title=Industry gets behind Project Canvas|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=9 September 2010|accessdate= }} Project Canvas evaluated the responses, with those selected to be taken through to the next stage of the evaluation process by the end of September. The initial target of Canvas was twin-tuner [[digital terrestrial television]] DVB-T2 IP-connected [[digital video recorder]]s (DVR).{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/technology/device-manufacturer/|title=Device Manufacturer|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=18 September 2010|accessdate= }} Project Canvas also welcomed a response from device manufacturers proposing other device categories, such as internet-enabled TV (IETV) and set-top boxes. Canvas devices would be made available to consumers though both retail channels and bundled with broadband packages. The service offer [[Video on demand|on-demand TV]]; from [[All 4|4oD]], [[BBC iPlayer]], [[My5|Demand Five]], and [[ITV Hub|ITV Player]];{{Cite web|url=http://www.YouView.com/questions/|title=YouView - Questions|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView|accessdate=18 September 2010}} and high-definition PVR capabilities without a monthly subscription fee, but will allow commercial broadcasters to use micro payments, and pre-, mid- and post-roll adverts to generate income.{{Cite web|url=http://MediaWeek.co.uk/news/1028931/YouView-will-encourage-competition-says-chief/|title=YouView will encourage competition, says chief|website=MediaWeek.co.uk|publisher=[[Media Week]]|date=16 September 2010}} The YouView [[Electronic program guide|electronic programme guide]] (EPG) will not carry any advertising, in line with the [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit]] aims of the business. While YouView will not have a payment system, commercial content owners will be able to insert their own, or use facilitators such as [[PayPal]]. In May 2010 the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that the name YouView was the most likely brand for the service, having been registered as [[intellectual property]] (IP) by the group of broadcasters in April.{{Cite news|url=http://www.FT.com/cms/s/0/c0f1b35a-6a80-11df-b282-00144feab49a.html|title=Project Canvas TV revolution faces delay|website=FT.com|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=28 May 2010|location=London|first=Tim|last=Bradshaw|first2=Andrew|last2=Parker|accessdate=30 May 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.TrustedReviews.com/home-cinema/news/2010/06/01/Project-Canvas-Facing-Delays--May-be-Called--YouView-/p1|title=Project Canvas facing delays, may be called 'YouView'|website=TrustedReviews.com|publisher=[[Trusted Reviews]]|date=1 June 2010|accessdate= }} On 16 September 2010 YouView TV Ltd was [[Corporation|incorporated]], and the product branded under the YouView name.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ProjectCanvas.info/index.cfm/news/?mode=alias&alias=YouView-unveiled-as-the-future-of-television|title='YouView' unveiled as the future of television|website=ProjectCanvas.info|publisher=Project Canvas|date=16 September 2010|accessdate= }} At the same time, Richard Halton was appointed as CEO of YouView TV Ltd, having previously served as programme director for Project Canvas. On 16 September 2010 a 'Notice of threatened opposition' was filed against YouView with the [[Intellectual Property Owners Association]] (IPO).{{Cite web|url=http://www.IPO.gov.uk/t-find-number?detailsrequested=H&trademark=2543659|title=Case details for Trade Mark 2543659|website=IPO.gov.uk|publisher=[[Intellectual Property Owners Association]] (IPO)|accessdate=24 September 2010}} Robin Fry, an intellectual property partner at law firm [[DAC Beachcroft|Beachcroft LLP]], said that the site's similarity to [[YouTube]] could cause consumers to confuse the two brands. The use of the world 'You', coupled with a capitalised character in the middle of the word, might suggest a connection between the services. If [[Google]] did object, it would be highly likely to win any legal action, according to Fry. "Google is involved in litigation all over the world, and would not be frightened of taking action against this trademark. It has a clear interest in protecting its trademarks to stop them being diluted", he said.{{Cite web|url=http://www.V3.co.uk/v3/news/2270368/legal-experts-argue-google|title=Google could take action over YouView brand|website=V3.co.uk|publisher=V3 - [[Incisive Media]]|date=24 September 2010|accessdate= }} On 4 November 2010, YouView appointed Adam & Eve as its [[advertising agency]] to create through-the-line advertising and communications. [[OMD Worldwide#Manning Gottlieb OMD|OMD]] was also appointed as YouView's planning and buying agency, and Momentum will act as YouView's specialist retail and experiential marketing agency. The teams are tasked with coordinating the brand launch and roll-out of YouView across all media and channels.{{Cite web|url=http://www.YouView.com/2010/11/04/youview-announce-agency-line-up/|title=YouView announce agency line-up|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView|date=4 November 2010|accessdate= }} On 14 April 2011, YouView announced additional hardware partnerships with [[Vestel]], [[Pace plc]], [[Huawei]], and Manhattan.{{Cite web|url=http://www.BroadbandTVNews.com/2011/04/14/youview-adds-four-manufacturers/|title=YouView adds four manufacturers|website=BroadbandTVNews.com|publisher=[[Broadband TV News]]|date=14 April 2011|accessdate= }} On 13 May 2011, Technicolor, one of the original set-top-box hardware manufacturing partners decided to withdraw from the project.{{Cite web|url=https://www.TheGuardian.com/media/2011/may/13/lord-sugar-youview-set-top-box/|title=YouView loses set-top box supplier|website=TheGuardian.com|publisher=Media Guardian|date=13 May 2011|accessdate= }} The six remaining manufacturers at that point were Humax, Huawei, Pace, Manhattan, Vestel, and Cisco. TalkTalk began running an in-house trial at the beginning of February 2012 to prepare for the launch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.BroadbandTVNews.com/2012/02/07/talktalk-youview-launch-on-track/|title=TalkTalk: YouView launch on track|website=BroadbandTVNews.com|publisher=Broadband TV News|date=7 February 2012|accessdate= }} ==On-demand players== On-demand players are available to all customers who have a YouView box connected to broadband. Players vary as rentals, on demand, subscription and catch-up. *[[BBC iPlayer]] (catch-up) *[[ITV Hub]] (catch-up) *[[All 4]] (catch-up & on-demand) *[[My5]] (catch-up) *[[Milkshake!|Milkshake]] (catch-up) *POP FUN (catch-up) *[[Now TV (Sky plc)|Now TV]] (subscription) *[[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky Store]] (rental) *[[UKTV]] ([[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]], [[Really (TV channel)|Really]], [[Yesterday (TV channel)|Yesterday]]) (catch-up) *[[TalkTalk TV|TalkTalk Player]] (for TT customers only) *[[BT TV|BT TV Player]] (for BT customers only) *[[Netflix]] Player (subscription) ==Technical information== On 14 April 2011, YouView published its final core technical specification. The minimum specifications for a YouView-enabled [[digital terrestrial television]] (DTT) [[High-definition video|high-definition]] (HD) [[digital video recorder]] (DVR or PVR) product require:{{Cite web|url=https://industry.YouView.com/resources/YouView_Core_Technical_Specification_1.0.pdf|title=YouView core technical specification|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView|date=14 April 2011|accessdate= }} *Twin [[DVB-T]]/[[DVB-T2]] tuners *[[Linux on embedded systems|Embedded Linux]] 2.6.23 or later operating system *Maximum of 26 [[Decibel#Acoustics|dB]] of fan noise *[[4K UHD]] ([[Ultra HD]]) graphics plane *[[MPEG-2]] and [[MPEG-4]] video *[[HDMI]] [[HDMI#Version 2.1|2.1]] socket *[[TOSLINK]] optical or [[Coaxial cable|coaxial]] [[S/PDIF]] connection *Up to [[5.1 surround sound]] *[[Ethernet]] port supporting [[Ethernet over twisted pair|10BASE-T]] and [[Fast Ethernet#100BASE-TX|100BASE-TX]] *[[IEEE 802.11n-2009|802.11n]] [[wireless network]] support, integrated, or via a USB adapter *950 [[Hertz#SI multiples|MHz]] [[central processing unit]] (CPU) *Two [[USB|Universal Serial Bus]] [[USB#USB 2.0|USB 2.0]] sockets *Support for [[USB mass storage device class|USB mass storage devices]] Analogue HD outputs are forbidden as part of the rights management strategy. The specifications will evolve over time to reflect different devices, including non-PVR and [[Freesat]] variants. ==Set-top boxes== [[Set-top boxes]] available for the YouView service: *[[Humax]] DTR-T1000 (launch date 24 July 2012). *[[Humax]] DTR-T1000 with [[BT Group|BT]] brand (launch date 1 September 2012). This includes the BT brand and an extra menu item "BT Vision".{{cite web|url=http://www.shop.bt.com/content/uni2/documentation/8qll/bt_youview_set_top_box.pdf|title=BT YouView Set Top Box documentation|author=|date=|website=bt.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/reviews/digital-home/3414419/bt-youview-humax-dtr-t1000-review/|title=BT YouView Humax DTR-T1000 review|author=Jim Martin|work=PC Advisor|date= |accessdate= }} *[[Humax]] DTR-T1010 (launch date 19 March 2013). The functionally and hardware is exactly the same to the previous DTR-T1000 with different appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.trustedreviews.com/humax-dtr-t1010_TV-recorder---set-top-box_review|title=Humax DTR-T1010|date=11 March 2013|website=TrustedReviews.com|accessdate= }} *[[Humax]] DTR-T2000 (launch date 14 June 2014). Minor redesign and slightly smaller than the previous T1010 design.{{cite web|url=https://community.YouView.com/youview/topics/youview_launches_new_retail_humax_box_dtr_t2000|title=YouView launches new retail Humax box: DTR-T2000|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView Community|date= |accessdate= }} *[[Humax]] DTR-T2100 with [[BT Group|BT]] YouView+ brand (launch date 25 February 2014). Redesign which is significantly smaller and quieter than previous Humax Youview boxes (because power transformer at plug).{{cite web|url=http://www.SeenIt.co.uk/bt-youview-box-2014-model-review/|title=BT YouView box (2014 model) review|author=Martin Hoscik|website=SeenIt.co.uk|publisher=SEENIT|date= |accessdate= }} *[[Humax]] DTR-T2110 with [[BT Group|BT]] YouView+ brand. *[[Humax]] DTR-T4000 with BT YouView+ Ultra HD band. *[[Huawei]] DN360T with [[TalkTalk Group|TalkTalk]] brand (launch date 5 March 2013). No recording is available. *[[Huawei]] DN370T with [[TalkTalk Group|TalkTalk]] brand (launch date 5 March 2013). Recording is available. *[[Huawei]] DN371T YouView+ (launch date 5 March 2014).{{cite web|url=http://www.HuaweiDevice.co.uk/news/March-5-2014/|title=Huawei consumer - Huawei news|website=HuaweiDevice.co.uk|date=5 March 2014|accessdate= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.HuaweiDevice.co.uk/home-devices/youview/|title=Huawei consumer – Huawei YouView|website=HuaweiDevice.co.uk|date= |accessdate= }}{{cite web|url=http://download-c.huawei.com/download/downloadCenter?downloadId=17844/|title=Huawei DN371T YouView Quick Start documentation|website=Huawei.com|date= |accessdate= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.SeenIt.co.uk/review-huawei-youview-set-top-box-dn371t/|title=Review: Huawei YouView+ set top box (DN371T)|author=Martin Hoscik|website=SeenIt.co.uk|publisher=SEENIT|date= |accessdate= }} *[[Huawei]] DN372T with [[TalkTalk Group|TalkTalk]] brand. Recording is available. Note 1: each YouView box comes in a variety of hard disk storage sizes, and is often designated by ModelNo/StorageSize – e.g. DTR-T1000/500GB Note 2: each YouView box does not have support for [[Wi-Fi]], and must connect directly to the router or through [[Power-line communication|power-line]] adapters. YouView have not allowed Wi-Fi in their software,{{cite web|url=http://support.YouView.com/articles/Self_Service_FAQ/Can-I-connect-my-YouView-box-wirelessly-1370864306799/|title=YouView public knowledge – can I connect my YouView box wirelessly?|website=YouView.com|publisher=YouView public knowledge|date= |accessdate= }} so USB Wi-Fi dongles will not work – however YouView suggest the use of a third-party (not supplied by YouView) [[Wireless Ethernet Bridge]] product may work, see YouView support for updated information. Note 3: YouView+ has become the designated way to show the set-top box records TV programmes. This is because of services offered by TalkTalk TV.{{cite web|url=http://www.YouView.com/get-youview/#quick-compare|title=How to get YouView and where to buy|publisher=YouView|date= |accessdate= }} ==Regulatory approval== ===BBC Trust approval=== On 26 February 2009, the [[BBC Trust]] launched a public consultation on the BBC Executive's proposal (Project Canvas) to develop a [[joint venture]] partnership to help enable the delivery of [[internet protocol television]] (IPTV), which would allow viewers to watch on-demand services, via television sets.{{Cite web|url=https://www.BBC.co.uk/bbctrust/news/press_releases/february/project_canvas.shtml|title=[BBC] Trust launches public consultation on proposal for internet protocol television (Project Canvas)|website=BBC.co.uk|publisher=[[BBC Trust]]|date=26 February 2009|accessdate= }} On 22 December 2009, the BBC Trust gave provisional approval to the BBC's involvement in Project Canvas after ruling that the likely public value of the proposal justifies any potential negative market impact.{{Cite web|url=https://www.BBC.co.uk/bbctrust/our_work/television/canvas_provisional_conclusions.shtml|title=[BBC] Trust assessment of 'Canvas' proposals – provisional conclusions|website=BBC.co.uk|publisher=[[BBC Trust]]|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= }} A period of consultation on the provisional conclusions closed on 2 February 2010. The BBC Trust has revealed that Project Canvas will cost over £115m in its first four years of operation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a185260/canvas-to-cost-gbp115m-in-first-four-years.html|title=Canvas to cost £115m in first four years|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=4 November 2009|accessdate= }} On 25 June 2010, the BBC Trust gave final approval to the BBC's involvement in Project Canvas, stipulating a number of conditions.{{cite press release|publisher=[[BBC Trust]]|date=25 June 2010|title=[BBC] Trust approves Project Canvas|url=https://www.BBC.co.uk/bbctrust/news/press_releases/june/canvas.shtml|website=BBC.co.uk|accessdate=25 June 2010}} The Trust concluded that Project Canvas will deliver significant public value for licence fee payers. The Trust will review the BBC's involvement in Canvas against the conditions of its approval, twelve months after launch of Canvas to consumers. The [[Digital TV Group]] (DTG) welcomed the decision, and is working with the Canvas partners and Virgin Media, Sky, and DTG members to develop the UK specification for Connected TV devices and services which will form the 7th edition of the DTG D-Book.{{Cite web|url=http://www.DTG.org.uk/news/news.php?id=3807|title=BBC Trust approves Project Canvas|website=DTG.org.uk|publisher=[[Digital TV Group]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate= }} A spokesman for [[Virgin Media]] said: "We are disappointed the BBC Trust has approved Canvas and ignored the significant concerns raised by the commercial sector about the proposal. Our position on this matter remains unchanged. As it stands, Canvas will severely restrict competition and innovation and ultimately this will harm consumers". A spokesman for [[British Sky Broadcasting]] (BSkyB) said: "The BBC's involvement in Canvas is an unnecessary use of public funds. The BBC Trust's announcement is a predictable decision from a body that has shown little inclination to think independently or set meaningful boundaries on the BBC's activities".{{Cite news|url=https://www.TheGuardian.com/media/2010/jun/25/project-canvas-bbc-trust|title=BBC Trust approves Project Canvas|website=TheGuardian.com|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=25 June 2010|location=London|first=Mark|last=Sweeney|first2=John|last2=Plunkett|accessdate=25 June 2010}} ====Main conditions of approval==== *'''Industry engagement''': completed elements of the Canvas core technical specification to be published within 20 working days from this final approval, and the Canvas partners to engage with industry on these and future elements of the technical specification. The final core technical specification will be published no later than eight months before launch of the first set-top boxes. The Trust will keep this process of engagement under review. *'''Free-to-air''': users will always be able to access Canvas free-to-air, though they may be charged for additional pay services that third parties might choose to provide via the Canvas platform, for example video on demand services, as well as the broadband subscription fees. *'''Accessibility and usability''': accessibility and usability features, such as audio description, should be incorporated into the core technical specification and/or user interface as soon as reasonably possible; and appropriate information and signposting should be provided for users to help them make informed choices about the suitability of content wherever possible. *'''Access to the platform for content providers and ISPs''': entry controls in terms of technical and content standards will be minimal, access will not be bundled with other products or services, listing on the [[electronic programme guide]] will be awarded in a fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory manner; and quality standards for ISPs delivering Canvas will be set at a minimum level and applied in a fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory manner. *'''Legal compliance''': Canvas will comply with all applicable laws, including competition and state aid law. *'''Cost''': the BBC's involvement will not exceed the Executive's estimated costs by more than 20 per cent over a five-year period. ====Comments==== Following the BBC's proposal in February 2009, there have been comments by a number of organisations and companies which have been published by the BBC in a 392-page document.{{Cite web|url=http://paidcontent.co.uk/article/419-canvas-views-summary/|title=Canvas views: Google wants in, responses to BBC digested|website=PaidContent.co.uk|publisher=paidContent:UK|date=4 June 2009|accessdate= }} The BBC Trust reached its provisional conclusions following more than 800 written responses.{{Cite news|url=http://news.BBC.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8426104.stm|title=Project Canvas given green light by BBC Trust|website=news.BBC.co.uk|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= }} The UK's [[Information Technology Telecommunications and Electronics Association|Intellect Technology Association]], said in a submission to the BBC Trust that Project Canvas risks isolating the UK as a "technological island" in a global market by trying to create a standard IPTV set-top box for just the UK.{{Cite web|url=https://www.TheRegister.co.uk/2009/05/08/project_canvas/|title=Electronics giants raise ruckus over Project Canvas|website=TheRegister.co.uk|publisher=[[The Register]]|date=8 May 2009|accessdate= }} [[British Sky Broadcasting]] has continuously, strongly criticised the project funding, saying that public money will be used to give public service broadcasters a foothold in the valuable IPTV, to the disadvantage of "the private sector".{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a155630/sky-criticises-bbc-trust-over-canvas.html|title=Sky criticises BBC Trust over Canvas|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=12 May 2009|accessdate= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a171929/sky-criticises-bbc-trust-over-canvas.html|title=Sky criticises BBC Trust over Canvas|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=17 August 2009|accessdate= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a181777/sky-publishes-canvas-criticisms.html|title=Sky publishes Canvas criticisms|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=13 October 2009|accessdate= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a188327/sky-continues-attack-on-canvas.html|title=Sky continues attack on Canvas|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=24 November 2009|accessdate= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.DigitalSpy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a192476/sky-slams-bbc-trusts-canvas-approval.html|title=Sky slams BBC Trust's Canvas approval|website=DigitalSpy.co.uk|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=22 December 2009|accessdate= }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.TheGuardian.com/media/organgrinder/2010/mar/17/market-project-canvas|title=The market doesn't need Project canvas|website=TheGuardian.com|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=17 March 2010|location=London|accessdate=22 May 2010|first=Mike|last=Darcey}} BSkyB is likely to raise state aid complaints if it appears that the BBC is shouldering the costs of developing the venture for its partners.{{Cite news|url=http://business.TimesOnline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/media/article7131232.ece|title=Free-to-air online TV project clears first hurdle|website=TimesOnline.cu.uk|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=20 May 2010|location=London|first1=Helen|last1=Power|accessdate=24 May 2010}} Sky estimates that it will lose four percent of revenue as a result of the project.{{Cite web|url=http://paidcontent.co.uk/article/419-canvas-vod-jv-approved-bbc-must-publish-specs-in-20-days/|title=Canvas VOD JV approved: BBC must publish specs in 20 days|website=PaidContent.co.uk|publisher=paidContent:UK|date=25 June 2010|accessdate= }} On 4 February 2010, ''The Guardian'' learned that in a submission to the BBC Trust as part of a final consultation on Project Canvas, the [[Digital TV Group]] said that there is "widespread concern" that the venture's partners are developing critical technology standards that do not involve key players such as set top-box manufacturers and TV makers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/feb/04/project-canvas-digital-tv-group|title=TV makers and retailers voice concerns over Project Canvas|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-02-04 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Sweney | accessdate=2010-05-22}} The DTG argue that the BBC Trust's provisional approval document does not contain a "clear and unequivocal condition" that Project Canvas will have to work with industry and there appears to be a "parallel process" taking place where Project Canvas and its preferred technology partners are developing a separate standard. [[Morgan Stanley]] compiled a creative analysis for BT about the potential impact of Canvas, describing it as "[[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] 2.0".{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a203561/report-canvas-will-be-freeview-20.html|title=Report: 'Canvas will be Freeview 2.0'|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-02-16}} Morgan Stanley noted that the BBC Trust will reach a final decision on the BBC's Canvas involvement at the end of March. If it gives the full green light, then the platform could enter launch phase by the end of the year or in early 2011. However, Morgan Stanley noted that any launch date would be dependent on the completion of major technical work, such as locking down specifications with manufacturers and also creating a workable electronic programming guide. Morgan Stanley expects that Canvas set-top boxes will cost between £150 and £200. The report predicts that an [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]]-style resource could be introduced to Canvas in the future, along with the integration of social networks such as [[Twitter]]. As Canvas will be an open platform, the report noted that content providers would no longer need to pay the current sum of around £10m for capacity on [[digital terrestrial television]] to reach their target audience. Internet service providers would also benefit from the service due an increased consumer demand for fixed broadband packages, along with greater opportunities to sell more expensive tariffs for high definition streaming. Storing popular programmes on local Canvas drives would also ease the burden of heavy streaming traffic over broadband networks. Considering outstanding issues facing the project, Morgan Stanley said: "Canvas looks pro-competitive (breaking down platform barriers for content owners), but some media companies could still try to challenge its creation. "It looks unlikely that this could freeze launch however as content is not being aggregated and the BBC shareholding will be only 16.6%." On 4 March 2010, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' learned that Neil Berkett, [[Virgin Media]]'s chief executive, would tell the Cable Congress in Brussels "the BBC Trust's consultation has been a shameless whitewash that contravenes almost every principle of good regulation."{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/media/7362359/Virgin-Media-attacks-BBC-Trust-over-Project-Canvas.html|title=Virgin Media attacks BBC Trust over Project Canvas|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=2010-03-04 | location=London | first=Rupert | last=Neate | accessdate=2010-05-22}} Mr Berkett objects to proposals to force all broadcasters to use a single 'Project Canvas' brand controlled by the BBC and its partners, which he claims will penalise commercial rivals. "The BBC Trust has stubbornly ignored all requests to address our concerns by imposing safeguards to prevent the BBC emerging as de facto gatekeeper of the digital world. This is a blatant demonstration that the Trust is incapable of regulating the BBC's activities in an objective way." On 28 April 2010, Neil Berkett confirmed that Virgin Media had made a submission to the Office of Fair Trading over Project Canvas.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/apr/28/virgin-media-sky-sports|title=Virgin Media eyes HD as it battles Sky for lower sports charges|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-04-28 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Sweney | accessdate=2010-05-22}} "Canvas needs to be an open platform but it is closed and will require a [second] dedicated set-top box," said Berkett. "We will oppose it vigorously if it is not an open world at large for customers to take advantage of. [The current proposals] are asking pay-TV customers to buy a second set-top box." He added that he considered it a misuse of the licence fee to create a product that was not accessible to all the public. "It is funded by the BBC licence fee and should be available everywhere, on a Virgin Box, a PS3 and even a Sky box," he said. "I find it extraordinary that it looks like the BBC Trust is endorsing what is a closed product. It is inappropriate for the BBC to be doing this." On 14 June 2010, Neil Berkett revealed to The Guardian that "Far from trying to block the development of these open standards, we have offered to work commercially with Canvas to explore mutually beneficial ways in which we could incorporate them as a self-contained service in the next generation of Virgin Media set-top boxes."{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/organgrinder/2010/jun/14/project-canvas-neil-berkett|title=Neil Berkett: why Virgin Media wants to work with Project Canvas|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-06-14 | location=London | first=Neil | last=Berkett | accessdate=2010-06-14}} Berkett went on to explain his opposition to the project; "The Canvas consortium has rejected the opportunity to incorporate Canvas into the Virgin Media customer experience, insisting that if we want to use their standards we must also accept that the entire Virgin Media entertainment service be accessed by our subscribers via a Canvas-imposed interface, including the Canvas channel listing and search facility. This "shop window" to services would be entirely controlled by the joint venture partners and would allow the Canvas partners to give preference and prominence to their own channel content above that of any other content provider. At this point, Canvas starts to look less like a set of genuinely "open" standards and more like a fully-fledged competing distribution platform from which established pay TV operators are effectively excluded, along with other innovative platforms offering a differentiated user experience, such as the PS3 and the Xbox. Unless we accept the Canvas consortium's conditions, people who want both Canvas and a pay TV service will have to buy two set-top boxes. Far from simplifying the digital world, Canvas will complicate it." On the BBC's involvement Berkett said: "Quite rightly, much attention has been focused on whether the BBC should be using the licence fee to bank-roll such a controversial intervention in a dynamic market. And it's true that many private sector companies are already investing precious capital in "connected TV". But it's the closed nature of the Canvas platform which gives the BBC's involvement significance. A set of standards that are genuinely open to all and to which the BBC has contributed is one thing. A proprietary gateway to the digital world, underpinned by the formidable brand and marketing muscle of the BBC, is quite another." On 5 March 2010, in a Q&A session at the DTG Summit, Richard Halton, then programme director for Project Canvas, faced criticism from Digital TV Group members about the lack of published technical specifications for the platform. In response, he asked members to appreciate the "tough and pretty challenging" schedule exerted on the project. However, Halton acknowledged the DTG's desire for more effective engagement with Canvas, and committed to publishing the remaining key technical documents by the end of May.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a207091/canvas-director-faces-dtg-grilling.html|title=Canvas director faces DTG grilling|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-03-05}} On 19 April 2010, 3view managing director John Donovan has said that he is "concerned" about the potential market impact of IPTV joint venture Project Canvas.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a215143/3view-md-concerned-by-project-canvas.html|title=3view MD 'concerned by Project Canvas'|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-04-19}} "The honest answer is that no-one has spoken to me from the BBC about what Canvas will entail. We do not understand what Canvas's remit will be and we do not subscribe to the belief that Canvas will provide something the commercial market can't. We have proved that we can do it," he told [[Digital Spy]]. Donovan declined to be drawn on whether 3view would consider a legal challenge to Canvas, but did say that his business will defend its ability to compete in the market. "I think we would have to reserve comment [on possible legal action]. But at this stage, clearly, we will protect our business at all costs. And I think, we will just have to leave it there for the moment." ===Office of Fair Trading approval=== On 22 March 2010, the Project Canvas partners submitted analysis to the [[Office of Fair Trading]] setting out why the proposed Canvas joint venture does not constitute a qualifying merger under the [[Enterprise Act 2002]]. On 19 May 2010, the OFT confirmed that it would not investigate Project Canvas over competition issues.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/may/19/oft-project-canvas|title=OFT clears Project Canvas|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-05-19 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Sweney | accessdate=2010-05-22}} As none of the partners were contributing a "pre-existing business" to Project Canvas, the OFT ruled that it "did not have the jurisdiction" to investigate the venture on competition grounds. "Unlike in the Project Kangaroo joint venture which was blocked by the Competition Commission in 2009, it is not proposed that the joint venture partners will contribute any video-on-demand content or other business to [Project] Canvas, and Canvas will have no role in aggregating, marketing or directly retailing any such television content," said the OFT. The OFT also said that it found that none of the partners would have a "material influence" over the policy of the venture – the "lowest level of control that may give rise to a relevant merger situation". ===Ofcom approval=== On 3 August 2010, Virgin Media lodged a complaint with [[Ofcom]] claiming that Project Canvas is an anti-competitive cartel that will crush the nascent online TV market.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/03/project-canvas-virgin-media-ofcom|title=Virgin Media aims to block Project Canvas with Ofcom complaint|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-08-03 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Sweney | accessdate=2010-08-03}} The cable TV company, which is also calling on the Office of Fair Trading to step in on the grounds that the venture breaches the Competition Act, argues that the six partners backing Project Canvas have not stuck to their stated pledge of creating a set of open standards for delivering next-generation TV services. "Collectively the BBC, ITV and Channel 4 account for around two-thirds of all television viewing in the UK while BT and TalkTalk control over half the national broadband market," said Virgin Media. "[Project Canvas] will stifle future innovation as well as eliminate existing consumer choice for home entertainment. These well-resourced companies usually are direct competitors in their respective markets but... they are establishing a single new TV platform of their own with a considerable incentive to favour this over other TV services. This could severely affect consumer options for watching public service programming in the future." Virgin Media has also complained that Project Canvas has wrongly rejected what the company considers fair offers of integrating the technology into its own set-top boxes with a compromise on user interface. "We have not taken the decision to file this complaint lightly," said a Virgin Media spokesman. "However, the Canvas partners have significantly exceeded their original claims to be creating a common set of open standards which could have been improved upon by others and are now intent on controlling every aspect of how people watch television." On 18 August 2010, [[IP Vision]] formally complained to Ofcom, calling on the regulator to examine the impact Project Canvas will have on innovation, competition and consumer choice.{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2010/08/18/ip-vision-says-canvas-is-bad-news-for-consumers/|title=IP Vision says Canvas is bad news for consumers|publisher=Broadband TV News|date=2010-08-18}} IP Vision is challenging the validity of Project Canvas, under the 1998 Competition Act. The company has already challenged the BBC over support for [[BBC iPlayer]]. On 30 August 2010, [[Six TV]], the largest holder of analogue television [[restricted service licence]]s in the UK (none of which are in use), announced that it would formally request a full Ofcom investigation of Canvas, warning that it could be a "poison pill" for regional broadcasters.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/30/six-tv-bbc-freeview-ofcom|title=Local TV group to complain to Ofcom over BBC-Canvas joint venture|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-08-30 | location=London | first=Richard | last=Wray | accessdate=2010-08-30}} Six TV will also submit its complaint regarding Canvas – which includes broader concerns regarding anti-competitive practices affecting digital television transmission in the UK – to the Office of Fair Trading. Six TV also intends to lobby communications minister [[Ed Vaizey]]. On 9 September 2010, United For Local TV an umbrella group which represents five local broadcasters with restricted service licenses (including Six TV), asked Ofcom to investigate the Project Canvas connected-TV venture on competition grounds.{{Cite web|url=http://paidcontent.co.uk/article/419-hyperlocal-tv-groups-team-to-rat-on-canvas-to-ofcom/|title=Hyperlocal TV Groups Team To Rat On Canvas To Ofcom |publisher=paidContent:UK|date=2010-09-09}} United For Local TV complained that qualification for including those services is "arbitrary", fees are charged that are "unrelated to a service provider's ability to pay", their channels would be hard to find on the EPG, the JV members may exploit viewer data "for commercial advantage" and Canvas could "prevent viewers from obtaining any streamed services on the open internet from TV channels who are unwilling or unable to meet the access terms." On 13 September 2010, the [[Open Source Consortium]], the UK trade body for organisations working in Open Source Software, submitted a formal objection {{Cite web|url=http://www.opensourceconsortium.org/project-canvas-ofcom-complaint/|title=Project Canvas – Ofcom Complaint|publisher=Open Source Consortium|date=2010-09-13}} to Ofcom asking it to investigate the project.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a276262/new-complaint-over-project-canvas-launch.html|title=New complaint over Project Canvas launch|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-09-13}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.techweekeurope.co.uk/workspace/open-source-consortium-opposes-bbcs-project-canvas-9700|title=Open Source Consortium Opposes Project Canvas|publisher=TechWeek Europe|date=2010-09-14}} In its submission to the media regulator, the [[Open Source Consortium|OSC]] said that Canvas will have "adverse consequences" for the device and software sector by "diminishing consumer choice and causing inevitable consumer harm". On 24 September 2010, ISBA – the trade body representing advertisers, joined a growing list of parties asking Ofcom to investigate YouView.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a278611/isba-asks-ofcom-to-investigate-youview.html|title=ISBA asks Ofcom to investigate YouView|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-09-24}} ISBA director of media and advertising Bob Wootton believes that the project could represent a "quasi-monopoly". Wootton also claimed that the BBC Trust's recent consultation on Canvas/YouView was "insufficient" for a platform that would carry advertising. On 28 September 2010, Electra Entertainment – a UK-based IPTV service provider, complained to media regulator Ofcom that YouView will "damage" the UK's interactive TV sector.{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a279117/ofcom-receives-another-youview-complaint.html|title=Ofcom receives another YouView complaint|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-09-28}} Electra has developed an IPTV platform, called Trove, which brings rich media services to the TV screen. It is currently available on Tesco-branded Freeview set top boxes. Electra believes that "the proposed vision, shareholder structure and aims of YouView are anti-competitive and significantly damage the UK interactive TV market". The firm also claimed that YouView's estimated initial marketing budget of £48 million is a "major cause for concern amongst venture capitalists looking to fund competing private British businesses in this emerging broadband TV sector". On 13 October 2010, British Sky Broadcasting submitted a last-minute complaint to Ofcom and the Office of Fair Trading.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/oct/13/bskyb-complaint-youview-ofcom|title=BSkyB submits 11th-hour complaint to Ofcom and OFT in bid to halt YouView|publisher=The Guardian|date=2010-10-13 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Sweeney | accessdate=2010-10-13}} The media regulator is now likely to delay a decision on whether to launch a full investigation into the service, previously called Project Canvas, while it considers Sky's objection. News of Sky's move prompted an angry reaction from the YouView chief executive, Richard Halton, "While we welcome justifiable scrutiny, the timing of this submission is clearly designed to extend the regulatory process in pursuit of commercial self-interest rather than the public interest", he said. Sky is believed to argue in its submission that the seven-partner YouView venture will stifle competition in the on-demand market. On 19 October 2010, Ofcom announced that it will not open an investigation into Project Canvas (YouView) under the Competition Act following complaints made by Virgin Media and IPVision.{{Cite web|url=http://media.ofcom.org.uk/2010/10/19/no-investigation-into-project-canvas/|title=No investigation into Project Canvas|publisher=Ofcom|date=2010-10-19}} Ofcom also received submissions from 11 other parties, including BSkyB. The regulator said that it is "premature" to open an investigation into YouView, as "whether or not YouView and its partners will harm competition in the ways alleged will depend upon how this emerging market develops and how they act, particularly in relation to providing access to content and issuing technical standards".{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a282888/ofcom-rules-out-youview-investigation.html|title=Ofcom rules out YouView investigation|publisher=Digital Spy|date=2010-10-19}} Ofcom noted that there is "little evidence" at this stage that YouView partners the BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 plan to restrict access to their video on-demand content. Ofcom do not propose to open a Competition Act investigation, however Ofcom will continue to monitor developments, particularly in relation to YouView’s approach to sharing standards and its effects on content syndication. If evidence emerges that the operation of YouView could cause harm to viewers and consumers in the future, Ofcom may reconsider whether to investigate. ==See also== {{Portal|Television|United Kingdom|Technology}} *[[Freeview (UK)#Freeview Play|Freeview Play]] *[[Kangaroo (video on demand)]] *[[Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV]] *[[Smart TV]] ==References== {{Reflist|32em}} ==External links== *[https://www.YouView.com https://www.YouView.com] — official website {{BBC}} {{UK Based TV on demand}} {{Media in the United Kingdom|television}} [[Category:BT Group]] [[Category:TalkTalk Group]] [[Category:BBC New Media]] [[Category:ITV]] [[Category:Channel 4]] [[Category:Channel 5 (UK)]] [[Category:Digital television]] [[Category:Internet television]] [[Category:Interactive television]] [[Category:Linux-based devices]] [[Category:Consumer electronics]]
